entries.content: Separate statements of fact from smoke screens or things said just to get rid of you. Not every objection is a dismissive brush-off.
Respond to statements and objections always in the form of a question to uncover the real meaning.
Challenge objections by asking clarifying questions that push the prospect to an extreme to see if it's truly insurmountable.
When a prospect says 'We're fine thanks', challenge with: 'Didn't you mean to say everything's perfect?'
entries.notes: Used to probe if 'fine' truly means 'perfect' or if there's room for improvement.

entries.content: Use clarifying questions to get the prospect to elaborate on their initial statement, revealing the nuance or root cause.
entries.notes: Example follow-up to 'everything's perfect': 'Oh, what do you mean?'

entries.content: When a prospect says 'I'm not interested', challenge with: 'When you say you're not interested, did you mean to say never ever under any circumstances would you consider exploring what we do?'
entries.notes: Pushes to an extreme to test the finality of the objection.

entries.content: When a prospect says 'We already have a supplier', challenge with: 'Would it be fair to say then that there is nothing anyone could say or do, no matter how cheaper or better, that you would ever consider exploring it?'
entries.notes: Isolates whether the existing supplier is a hard barrier or if they are open to exploring alternatives under specific conditions.

entries.content: When a prospect says 'I don't take cold calls', ask simply: 'What do you mean?'
entries.notes: A simple clarifying question to understand the specific reason behind the statement.

entries.content: Asking clarifying questions helps establish if the prospect's statement is a genuine fact or an easy way to end the call.
Don't take prospecting objections too seriously. View them as opportunities to practice asking probing questions.

focus_area: Objection Discovery: Clarifying questions, isolation, root cause
